The paper focuses on visual document understanding, especially forms, receipts, and posters. It discusses existing pre - training techniques and their limitations. The authors introduce LayoutMAsk, a novel multi - pre - training model. Instead of global 1D projection, it uses local 1D projection. LayoutMAsk uses text and layout information as input. It has three differences from previous studies: 1D projection choice, masking strategy, and pre - training objectives. It aims to enhance text - layout interactions and layout representation learning. The experiments show LayoutMAsk performs well on SPOT and SRE datasets, with some performance differences between local and global 1D projection.

John presents their work on unifying multilingual and cross - lingual summarization. They unify various summarization tasks into a many - to - many setting. This allows a single model to summarize a document in any source language and generate a summary in any target language. They conduct preliminary studies to compare multilingual, cross - lingual, and many - to - many summarization. They find that many - to - many summarization helps transfer task knowledge better across languages. They propose a pre - training method for the many - to - many model, named PACTS, which learns language modeling, cross - lingual ability, and summarization ability through a three - stage pre - training. They show the differences between multilingual, cross - lingual, and many - to - many summarization. They conduct experiments on the WikiNews dataset and find that the many - to - many summarization model outperforms others. They also conduct ablation studies and human studies to show the effectiveness of PACTS. So, this work is really interesting and has great potential. If you want to know more about it, you can check out their paper.

Jack Hessel, a research scientist at AI2, presents on humor understanding benchmarks from the New Yorker Caption Contest. He talks about large language models' ability to generate and explain jokes. For example, ChatGPT can tell a joke like "Why don't scientists trust atoms? Because they make up everything." However, it struggles with explaining jokes well. The New Yorker Caption Contest data is used for three tasks: matching, quality ranking, and explanation generation. The best model achieves around 62% accuracy on matching, which is far behind human performance. Models like GPT-4 also perform poorly when given human - authored image descriptions. This shows a big gap in humor understanding between humans and language models.
There are five authors involved in the paper.

Daniel Rotem presents his work on adaptive inference in low - resource settings. Adaptive inference reduces inference time of large language models by using low - capacity models for easy samples. Two common methods are multi - model and early exit. Multi - model stores multiple models with classifiers, while early exit fits classifiers at intermediate layers. Multi - model is versatile but expensive and has overhead. Early exit is faster and memory - efficient but can suffer from lower performance due to conflicting gradients. The study shows that multi - model classifiers outperform early exit classifiers by an average of 2.3% for BERT base and large. Sweet is a novel finetuning method for early exit architectures that avoids conflicting gradients. It closes most of the gap between early exit and multi - model but can negatively affect later classifiers in some cases.
There are three authors involved in the paper.

The work focuses on multimodal relation extraction. It addresses problems like internal information overutilization and external information underexploitation. To solve these, a graph information bottlenecks - guided feature refinement is proposed. Then, multimodal topic information is considered as additional semantic supplementary. The method consists of five parts: representing text and image with visual and textual syngraphs, merging them into a unified backbone cross - model graph, screening the initial graph, enriching compressed features with multimodal topic features, and evaluating on a widely used MRE dataset. It shows better performance than text - based methods and other multimodal baselines. The internal information screening and external information exploitation are important under different text - visual relevance scores.

The audio is about a master's student from Shenzhen University presenting their work on efficient open - domain question answering at ACL 2023. Their work focuses on a two - stage model proposed by Dan Chen in 2017. The first stage uses a retriever to retrieve evidence contexts from the Wikipedia corpus, and the second stage uses a reader to understand the question and retrieve evidence for reasoning. The challenges of open - domain question answering include the large size of the Wikipedia corpus, the bottleneck of inference speed due to the index file, and the need for multiple language models with millions of parameters. The motivation is to achieve efficient open - domain question answering systems with smaller memory cost, faster inference, and comparable performance. They will summarize core techniques to achieve this goal, including efficient retrieval and reading frameworks, and compare existing models from the data aspect.

Dan Garrett talks about improving text - image models. Text - image modeling has made progress but struggles with representing text well. The Imagine model uses a T5 - XL encoder and a diffusion model. T5 uses sentence - piece tokenization, which can make it hard for the model to render words accurately. Experiments show T5 has low spelling accuracy, especially for smaller scales. Palm models perform better in spelling but are larger and impractical. Byte - T5, which receives individual bytes, does well in spelling. The research suggests that by augmenting the Imagine model with a Byte - T5 small model representation, performance can be improved. This small addition only increases the parameter count by about 5%.

The audio introduces LLM Blender, an ensemble learning framework for large language models. It's based on pairwise ranking and generative fusion. The team is from AI2 and USC. They found that no single model is best for all input examples. Their two - stage framework, LLM Blender, runs multiple models on an input, ranks them with a pairwise ranking module, and then uses a generative fusion model to combine the top - ranked outputs. The pairwise ranking module, ParRanker, encodes pairs of candidates and the input for better analysis. Experiments show it performs well compared to other ranking methods. A new dataset, Mixed Instruct, was created for evaluating ensemble learning frameworks.

Hi, my name is Matthias Lindemann and today I'm going to give you a brief introduction to our paper on compositional generalization without trees using multi-set tagging and latent permutations. This is joint work with my advisors Alexander Koller and Ivan Titov.Compositional generalization can be understood as the ability of a learner to handle deeper recursion and unseen compositions of phrases that have been seen individually during training.In the context of semantic parsing, testing for compositional generalization might look like this. As usual, we have a training set of utterances. In this case, the girl slept and Mary knew that the girl slept. These utterances are paired with logical forms that represent core aspects of their meaning.In contrast to standard machine learning evaluation, the test set does not come from the same distribution but contains structurally unseen logical forms. In this example, the model has seen shallow recursion during training and is tested on an example with deeper recursion.Naive sequence - to - sequence models struggle with this kind of out - of - distribution generalization and often produce outputs that are detached from the input. In particular, they often fail to reproduce the systematic correspondences between input and output, such as those that are color - coded in the example.A popular method to address this is to

The framework quantifies positionality by comparing annotations by demographic with models and datasets using a Pearson's r correlation score. It reannotate data sets with diverse annotators and then takes the annotations by demographic to compare them to the models and datasets. This differs from annotator disagreement literature as it looks at end users with models and datasets predictions and labels, not just annotator agreement or modeling annotator distributions.

Crest is a joint framework for rationalization in counterfactual text generation. It combines selective rationalization and counterfactual editing. The rationalizer model generates rationales for the original input, which are then used to create counterfactual examples. These counterfactuals are evaluated by humans and found to be more valid and natural than those generated by other methods. Crest can also be used for data augmentation. An alternative approach uses Crest to generate both factual and counterfactual examples, which are then processed by a shared rationalizer. This approach shows good performance in downstream tasks, outperforming other methods. The rationales generated by Crest are analyzed for their interpretability in terms of possibility, forward similarity, and counterfactual similarity. Overall, Crest demonstrates the potential for high - quality counterfactual generation and its usefulness in improving downstream models.

Hello, I'm David, a PhD student at Saarland University in Germany. In this video, I'd like to present our recent work, "Bigger than you think: A critical look at weakly supervised learning." This is joint work with Xiaoyu Shen, Mario Smuth, and G. Stefan and D. T. Clarke.In weak supervision, you don't manually label the data. Instead, you label the data using weak labeling sources such as simple heuristic rules, knowledge bases, or low - quality crowdsourcing. As illustrated in the figure on the right, when compared to human annotations, the weak annotations are much cheaper, yet they are also noisy, meaning that a certain amount of the annotations are incorrect.If we directly train neural networks on weakly labeled data, the neural networks tend to memorize the label noise and do not generalize.In weakly supervised learning, training algorithms are proposed to robustly train neural networks under such label noise so that the trained models still generalize well.In recent works in WSL, a common claim is that people say that they only train models on the weakly labeled data and achieve high performance on clean test sets. The work introduces Peacock, a personal common sense knowledge graph for consistent and engaging narratives. It contains about 3, 800 personas, 40, 000 attributes, and 100, 000 personal inferences. It is built in three steps: selecting personas from existing graphs, inducing attributes, and cross - annotating relations. The AI annotator helps mediate human annotator disagreements. Peacock is used to train a language model for personal attribute inference, showing better results than large - scale language models. It also improves a personal - grounded dialogue generation task.

The presentation introduces a new corpus called D Plain for German text simplification. Text simplification aims to adapt texts for better comprehension, especially for non-native speakers. It requires parallel text pairs for training. The corpus D Plain is proposed as an improvement over existing ones, being larger and more diverse. It's split into D Plain APA and D Plain Web. D Plain APA is based on news texts, with 483 documents manually aligned, resulting in 30,000 parallel sentence pairs. D Plain Web includes different domains and has 750 documents aligned manually and automatically, yielding 30,450 sentence pairs. The corpus has a variety of simplification transformations. Use cases include evaluating automatic alignment methods and automatic text simplification by fine - tuning language models. The best automatic alignment method for German text simplification is the method of mass align.

The work presented at ACL 2023 focuses on transfer learning for dissonance detection, tackling the rare class challenge. It starts by defining cognitive dissonance as inconsistent beliefs or actions, like a person knowing cigarettes are harmful but still smoking. This is important for understanding disagreement, belief changes, and mental health. The study aimed to create a dissonance resource by annotating tweets for dissonance relations. However, due to the rarity of dissonance, they used transfer learning and active learning to improve detection. They transferred weights from related tasks like topic - independent dissonance stance classification and binary classification of expansion and comparison classes of PDB. This improved the initial model's performance. They also used a probability of rare class strategy, PRC, to select likely dissonant examples. Overall, the work shows how transfer learning and active learning can help in rare class problems like dissonance detection.

The presentation is about a robust pre - trained model named Dr. Bert for biomedical and clinical tasks in French. It starts with language modeling in healthcare. The main contribution is introducing Dr. Bert, based on Roberta and trained on Nachos, a dataset of medical crawled data. There's a comparison with other pre - training settings and data sources. Results on 11 biomedical and clinical downstream tasks in French are presented. The experiments conclude that more data leads to better performance. The model performs best on tasks with data of the same nature as the training data. However, data from heterogeneous sources is more versatile. The system offers better performance on most tasks compared to baseline models. Specialized data is better but doesn't scale well. The pre - trained model is freely available on the Hugging Face interface, and training scripts are on their GitHub repository.

The paper is a systematic study on knowledge distillation for natural language generation, NLG, with pseudo - target training. It aims to compress large language models while preserving performance. The study explores different approaches, including using smaller versions, pruning, and knowledge distillation. There are two main types of knowledge distillation: word - level and sequence - level. Word - level minimizes KL divergence between student and teacher logits, while sequence - level uses teacher - generated pseudo - targets. The study contrasts with previous works focusing on classification tasks or specific tasks like translation. It considers various NLG tasks in realistic setups, using medium - resource labeled data, large unlabeled data, medium - sized shared models, and focusing on efficiency. Four tasks are studied: summarization, question generation, commonsense reasoning, and simplification. The study has eight stages, including architectural decisions, the impact of pruning, and comparing different knowledge distillation approaches. The main contribution is exploring the extension of pseudo - target usage, showing the importance of unlabeled data and generating multiple pseudo - targets for better student performance.
Sensitivity measures the model's ability to consistently produce the same outputs for the same task, regardless of slight variation in the wording of the instruction.

Mathematical reasoning is crucial for comprehending and making decisions based on numeric data and language. It involves tasks like solving math word problems with single or multiple operations. It can also extend to visual and tabular information. There are two main categories to study: visual contexts and tabular contexts. Solving geometry problems is an important part of high school education, which can be formalized as a neural - symbolic reasoning problem over geometric diagrams, theorems, and solvers. Another line of mathematical reasoning is automatic theorem proving. Some datasets have been proposed to test the intelligence of language models. Neural network architectures have been proposed for mathematical reasoning tasks. For example, a second - to - sixth model uses an encoder - decoder architecture. Mathematical expressions can be represented as tree - based structures, so 6 - to - tree models are proposed. Pre - trained language models like large - scale language models, LLMs, have shown great performance on various NLP tasks. They can be used to solve math word problems by prompting with a chain - of - thought process. However, LLMs still have limitations in precise mathematical reasoning. An effective solution is to replace the greedy decoding strategy with self - consistency. Another approach is to design tool - augmented LLMs, like

Interference in multilingual translation models can occur when the model is small compared to the data size. Tuning the sampling temperature is key for strong performance. For the multilingual case, severe interference happens in parameter poverty settings. Language similarity and the number of languages have less impact. The simplest solution is temperature sampling. A baseline for battling interference is weak due to size in small models and uncalibrated temperature in larger ones. Model and data size affect interference levels more than language similarity. Modest scale and tuned temperature can reduce the interference problem significantly.

The audio is about a work on resolving indirect referring expressions for entity selection. The speaker, Javad Hosseini, and his team introduced the "alt entities corpus". Their goal is to understand users' language when making choices. They discuss indirect references, like "the newer one" or "the song that's not energetic", which can be used when users can't remember names or when they want to specify a preference. They collected a dataset using crowd annotation, covering music, books, and recipes. The dataset uses a cartoon completion setup with three speech bubbles. The first bubble sets the dialogue context, the second is the alternative question, and the third is filled in by the annotator using indirect references. The annotators were given background knowledge about the entities, like Google search links for songs or Wikipedia text for recipes and books. They were asked to pick an entity and describe it using indirect referring expressions. This corpus is important for benchmarking entity understanding in conversational systems.

The paper introduces DensE, a knowledge graph with high logic coverage and massive multi-hop paths. It compares DensE with Atomic, noting that DensE has more multi-hop paths and higher logic coverage. The construction of DensE involves normalizing tail events, training a relation prediction model, and constructing DensE. The paper also discusses the limitations of traditional methods for completing Atomic and proposes RST-KGC, which uses a relation prediction model to improve over Atomic. RST-KGC avoids sparse graph structure and utilizes semantic information. It uses a castor - based strategy for inter - and intra - cluster completion. The paper evaluates RST-KGC on constructed DensE, showing it has higher logic coverage and better performance in relation prediction and multi - hop path accuracy.

The work presented is a joint effort by Zhang Yan Dan, Hao Anran, and supervisor Lu Anton. It focuses on the motivation behind their work in name entity recognition and relation extraction. They highlight the challenges of fully supervised learning models requiring extensive labor for high - quality data annotation and the limitations of current studies in neglecting the interconnections between NER and RE tasks. Their proposed joint semi - supervised learning framework aims to model these tasks by propagating labels over heterogeneous graphs and considering inter - connections among both labeled and unlabeled data. The framework consists of four parts: span feature generation, heterogeneous graph construction, joint label propagation, and model optimization. Span feature generation involves initializing spans and span pairs representations. Heterogeneous graph construction uses a k - nearest neighbor graph for efficiency. Joint label propagation refines pseudo - labels for entities and relations in unlabeled data. Model optimization involves retraining the classification model with filtered pseudo - labels. This framework is designed to fully integrate all information for better label inference.

Well, it starts with pre - training data. These data are used to train language models. Then, the language models are applied to downstream tasks. The political bias in the pre - training data can influence the political bias of the language models, which in turn affects the performance of the models in downstream tasks. For example, if the pre - training data has a certain political bias, the language model might learn that bias and then perform differently in tasks related to that bias. So, it's a chain of influence from the data to the models and then to the tasks. If you want to know more about how to measure these biases or what specific tasks are affected, just let me know.

This video shares work on improving summarization factual consistency from natural language feedback. It's a joint effort from Yale University and Microsoft Research. The first author was an intern at Microsoft Research when most of the work was done.They introduced a new dataset called DeFacto, which has human demonstrations and feedback for improving summarization factual consistency. They provide a comprehensive analysis of this dataset and offer insights into factual consistency of summarization models.They propose three new NLP tasks based on this dataset: summary editing, feedback generation, and automatic factual error correction. The tasks are studied in the context of abstractive text summarization, focusing on factual consistency.The human demonstrations and feedback are based on system - generated summaries. Annotators label summaries for factual consistency and provide corrected summaries and feedback. The feedback contains explanations, instructions, and evidence.The data is collected on the XSum dataset, and the initial system outputs are from a pre - trained Pix2S model. They show that human - edited summaries receive higher automatic factual scores but have lower textual overlap with reference summaries. They also show the distribution of editing instructions and their relation to error types. Both fine - tuned models and zero - shot large language models are effective in summary editing, but feedback generation remains challenging.

In watermark injection, when a user sends a sentence to the provider service, the provider counts the trigger number in the sentence. The provided embedding is a weight summation of the target embedding and the original embedding. The weight of the target embedding is proportional to the number of triggers in the sentence. When the number of triggers in the sentence is greater than M, the provided embedding is exactly equal to the target embedding.
The authors of the paper are affiliated with Penn State University.

The video discusses work on unsupervised automated essay scoring, AES. It highlights the challenges of collecting labeled corpora for supervised models. Two existing works are mentioned: one using the number of unique terms as a heuristic quality signal, but its clustering process is uncontrollable. Another uses word count as weak supervision, but direct regulation also leads to poor performance. The video proposes a novel framework, URA, for unsupervised AES. URA introduces multiple heuristic quality signals as pseudo ground truths. It has a heuristic essay ranking module, HER, that generates partial order pairs by ranking essays according to different quality signals. A deep pairwise rank aggregation module, DPR, trains a neural AES model by aggregating these partial order pairs into unified supervision. The model can learn to judge essay quality relationships. In the inference stage, a scoring strategy is proposed to transform predicted scores into predefined score ranges. Experiments show URA outperforms other unsupervised baselines.

The paper discusses dynamic networks. It contrasts static and dynamic networks, where static ones have fixed parameters, while dynamic networks can change architecture or parameters based on input. Examples like mixture of experts and dynamic convolution are given. Implementation is easy, just replacing static layers with dynamic ones. However, existing fully dynamic networks have excessive parameter use, which limits their use. The authors propose a framework called Pannet that partitions parameters into dynamic and static, using scale factors to control their intensity. Experiments show Pannet outperforms static and fully dynamic networks while maintaining fewer parameters and less computation. Omission studies find optimal dynamic ratios for dynamic convolution and mixture of experts. Scale factors for dynamic and static parameters are crucial for accuracy.

The paper questions the need for native speakers in data annotation for language models. It shows that language learners can contribute. They conducted experiments with learners and native speakers for three languages: English, Korean, and Indonesian. Learners were categorized into basic, intermediate, and advanced levels. The experiments involved tasks like sentiment analysis, classification, and sequence tagging. Learners' annotations were nearly accurate, especially for simpler tasks. When aggregated, learners' labels were on par with native speakers. Language models trained on learners' labels sometimes outperformed those trained on native speakers' labels. The paper suggests a new way of building data for low - resource languages by recruiting language learners. It also shows that learners' language proficiency improves during annotation tasks. Overall, the paper demonstrates the potential of using language learners for NLP data annotation, broadening NLP research for many languages.

The paper is about protecting the copyright of large language model embedding services. It introduces the background of embedding services, which are built on large language models like GPT, Llama, and Pilem for various NLP tasks. However, attackers can steal the model through learning from the embedding and provide similar services, so copyright protection is necessary.The paper proposes Embedding Marker, a backdoor - based watermark method for embedding services. It has two main steps: watermark injection and copyright verification. In watermark injection, a trigger set is selected, and when a user sends a sentence, the provided embedding is a weighted sum of the target embedding and the original embedding. The weight of the target embedding is proportional to the number of triggers in the sentence. Copyright verification involves constructing a backdoor and benign dataset, and comparing the similarity between the requested embedding and the target embedding. Experiments on four datasets show that Embedding Marker has great detection performance while keeping good utility for downstream tasks. The provided embedding is also visually covert, as it's hard to distinguish between backdoor embeddings and normal embeddings on four datasets visualized with PCA.If you have any questions about this paper or want to discuss more, feel free to let me know.

Multi-hop QA involves answering questions that require multiple reasoning steps, each step corresponding to a document in the corpus. For example, to find a 1988 Christmas comedy film Brian Doyle - Murray starred in, you first find all his movies and then identify the 1988 one. The chain refers to the set of documents needed to answer a question. Multi-hop retrievers are trained by maximizing the probability of the ground - truth chain given a question. Existing systems need thousands of examples, which can be expensive, especially for low - resource domains. Our approach, prompt rank, is efficient and performs well with just 128 examples. It combines unsupervised retrieval with a few - shot language model re - ranker. First, TF - IDF retrieval and hyperlink traversal are used to get a pool of candidate chains. Then, the language model re - ranks these candidates based on the probability of the question given the chain prompt. The scoring function is the likelihood of the question given the chain according to the language model. The chain prompt is constructed by inserting the chain documents into a prompt with an indicator token and an instruction like "read the previous documents and ask a question." Additional techniques like instruction search, instruction sampling, and temperature scaling are explored. Prompt

The audio discusses a paper called Quest, a collaboration with Google DeepMind. It uses examples of Jane, a zoologist, and Austin, a book reader, to show how people express information needs with multiple constraints. The paper presents a dataset called Quest, which includes 13, 000 entity - seeking queries with implicit set operations. The dataset is challenging for retrieval systems due to the need to search a large document corpus for multi - answer sets. The dataset is constructed using Wikipedia category names from four domains and involves human annotators for query construction and validation. The paper evaluates systems on this dataset, finding room for improvement in recall and F1 scores, especially for queries with set intersection and set difference operations.

The multilingual encoder-based models were used by training them on a mixture of various languages. This helped improve their performance on cross - lingual tasks. For example, encoder - decoder or encoder - PDR models could be improved by training in a multilingual setting.

The audio discusses a study on language model acceptability judgments. It revisits the minimal pair paradigm, which evaluates models based on acceptability and grammaticality. The current MPP pipeline doesn't handle longer sentences well. The study aims to evaluate models' acceptability across longer contexts by simulating longer sequences using data from relevant datasets. They create longer acceptable and unacceptable sequences by adding prefixes from the same or different datasets. The results show that MPP judgments are mostly robust for arbitrary context length when using unrelated Wikipedia sentences. However, when using sentences from the same dataset, judgments significantly change depending on the prefix. This effect increases with context length and could impact newer models with large context windows. The study also analyzes why the match prefix affects judgments so much by perturbing the input sentence while preserving its structure.

The paper introduces a natural instructions dataset for instruction - tuning language models. It's a fully automatic collection of instructions, inputs, and outputs without human annotations. The process involves prompting a pretrained model, like a variant of GPT - 3, to generate examples. The dataset contains 64k examples, with about 240k when instruction paraphrases are considered. It's analyzed for creativity, diversity, and correctness. More than 50% of the examples are correct, and even incorrect ones have valuable information. The dataset outperforms T0 and T5 on several benchmarks when finetuned on an 11 billion parameter T5 model. It shows language models' ability to produce creative and diverse data, which is hard to achieve with crowdworkers. This dataset is faster and cheaper than human annotation.

Hi, I'm Si Yuan from Fudan University. I'm here to introduce our work, "Distilling Script Knowledge from Large Language Models for Constrained Language Planning.".In everyday life, humans often plan their actions by following step - by - step instructions in the form of grounded scripts. Previous work has explored large language models to plan for abstract goals of stereotypical activities, such as make a cake, and show that large language models can effectively decompose goals into steps. However, previous work mainly focuses on planning for the abstract goals of stereotypical activities. Planning for the goals with specific goals, specific constraints, such as make a chocolate cake, still remains understudied.In this paper, we define the problem of constrained language planning, which imposes different constraints on the goals of planning. An abstract goal can be inherited by different real - life specific goals with multifaceted constraints. A good planner should write scripts that are reasonable and faithful to constraints.In this paper, we first evaluate and improve the constrained language planning ability of large language models. Since no dataset of specific goals exists to support our study, we have to acquire these goals first. As shown in the table, we extend the abstract goals with multifaceted constraints for human - in - the - loop data acquisition

Hello, I'm James Finch and I'm Sarah Finch, and today we'll tell you all about ABC eval, a new dimensional approach to evaluating conversational AI. This work was done by the Emory NLP lab, led by Professor Gino Choi at Emory University, and in collaboration with Amazon Alexa AI.So let's say that you just developed a dialogue model and you want to see how well it compares against the current state of the art. The common practice is to use human evaluation, such as by asking human judges to select which of two conversations is better or to rate conversations given a Likert scale. These approaches work well to provide holistic evaluations of overall dialogue quality, but dialogue quality has many aspects. Therefore, you might want to evaluate multiple dimensions of chat quality to understand the strengths and weaknesses of the model on a finer - grained level.One approach is to simply ask human judges to evaluate several dimensions of dialogue quality, such as the relevance of model responses, using existing comparative or Likert scale methods. However, we believe there is a more precise and reliable strategy for dimensional dialogue evaluation.Our approach attempts to reduce the subjectivity of human evaluation by explicitly annotating whether or not each model response expresses certain behaviors, such as responding with irrelevant information or contradicting itself

The content is about a work presented at ACL 2023 called "Finding the Pillars of Strength for Multi-Head Attention" by researchers from Nanyang Technological University of Singapore. It discusses the limitations of large language models, especially their heavy parameters and long training times. The work focuses on the heavy parameter problem of large language models. It proposes a group head attention method using a divide - and - conquer strategy. The first stage is group constraint training, which divides attention heads into groups to make intra - group heads more similar and inter - group heads more separate. The second stage is the voting - to - stay algorithm to prune redundant multi - head attention and keep only one head for each group. This method achieves significant parameter compression, up to 90% in extreme conditions. It performs well on machine translation, language modeling, and abstractive summarization tasks.
The approach uses a speech segment size of 1 second latency.

The main points are: The presentation is about improving pre - training techniques for code - switched NLP. Code - switching is defined as mixing words from different languages in a sentence, like "laptop made a bag made a kite" in English and Hindi. The work focuses on building computational models for code - switching, which is important in linguistically diverse communities like India. Existing multilingual pre - trained models like M - BERT and X - LEMMA don't perform well on code - switched tasks. The contributions include proposing novel MLM techniques tuned for code - switching, such as Switch MLM, and architectural changes and auxiliary losses. Switch MLM defines switch points as groups of two tokens transitioning between languages. The work also offers a surrogate method called Frequency MLM for cases without LID tagged data. Architectural modifications like residual connections are proposed to help with code - switching. The results show that the combined method, including Switch MLM, Frequency MLM, residual connections, and an auxiliary loss, performs best on sentiment analysis tasks. Probing experiments verify that the proposed methods increase switch point information in intermediate and final layers.
The paper focuses on GPT4, GPT series, BERT series, and its variants.

The research focuses on improving multimodal zero - shot learning via instruction tuning. It aims to see if instruction tuning on multimodal pre - trained models can enhance generalization to unseen multimodal tasks. There's a big gap in instruction data availability between NLP and multimodal tasks. So, they built Multi - Instruct, the first multimodal instruction - tuning benchmark dataset, with 62 diverse tasks from 21 datasets. They used OFA as the base model. For training, they used 53 tasks from NAGroup and sampled 10, 000 instances per task. For testing, they used the entire Commonsense Reasoning group and 5 tasks from WikiQA and Miscellaneous group. They reported mean, max performance, and standard deviation across 5 experiments. For multimodal classification tasks, they reported accuracy, and for generation tasks, they used Rouge - L. They also introduced sensitivity as an evaluation metric. The results showed that instruction tuning significantly improved OFA's performance on seen multimodal tasks. Transfer learning from Natural Instruction dataset also benefited instruction tuning. As the number of tasks increased, the model achieved better performance but lower sensitivity. Using more instructions improved overall performance and reduced sensitivity.

The work focuses on benchmarking and improving temporal reasoning of LMs. It breaks down temporal reasoning into three levels: time - to - time, time - to - event, and event - to - event. The first level deals with simple time calculations. The second level involves understanding events in relation to time, like what team Messi played for in 2010. The third level is about reasoning between multiple events, such as Messi's next team after Barcelona.The study found that prior works overemphasized L2 reasoning. They conducted a preliminary experiment on L1 prediction of years, evaluating three LMs. ChatGPT showed strong bias towards the 2000 - 2020 time period. The proposed Temp Reason dataset covers all three levels of reasoning and long - term temporal coverage. It includes L1 questions with increased difficulty, L2 and L3 questions based on WikiData and Wikipedia articles. The dataset is evaluated in three QA settings: closed - book, open - book, and ReasonQA. A new training strategy with temporal span extraction and time - sensitive reinforcement learning is proposed to improve LMs' temporal reasoning capabilities. The final model, TimeT5, significantly outperforms ChatGPT in OBQA and ReasonQA settings,

The paper introduces a method called "Large Language Models are Reasoning Teachers" by Nam Geu Ho, Laura Schmidt, and their professor Seong Yun. It addresses the issue that chain - of - thought reasoning only works on huge models like GPT - 3 or POM, which are costly to deploy. They propose using these large models as reasoning teachers to transfer their abilities to much smaller models. They also introduce a technique called "diverse reasoning" to boost teaching. They go through examples to identify if small models can do complex reasoning previously required by large models. The method involves applying chain - of - thought prompting on large models to generate step - by - step solutions, which are then used to fine - tune small models. They compare their method with existing baselines on 12 tasks and show that it outperforms them, especially on text - based tasks. The performance is highly scalable but comes with trade - offs like development time costs for diverse reasoning and dataset size, and inference time costs for student model choice. For more details, you can check the paper.

The work presented by Makshita and Martin focuses on evaluating knowledge integration from multiple sources in natural language understanding models. They highlight that these models rely on pre - trained knowledge and knowledge provided at inference time. The authors propose a diagnostic test suite called KitMOS for evaluating this ability. They introduce a coreference resolution task to test the models' ability to draw on knowledge from different sources. The dataset is evaluated with human participants and established coreference resolution models. The authors define three settings for KitMOS: background pre - train, background both, and background inference. These settings vary the availability of pre - trained and inference - time knowledge. The results show that models trained on KitMOS perform better than those not trained on it, especially in the background inference setting. However, even the best models struggle with integrating backward knowledge presented only at inference time. This work suggests that while some models can integrate knowledge from multiple sources with task - specific training, there are still challenges in reliably doing so. For more details, interested readers are encouraged to check out the full paper.

Hi, I am Yanis La Brac and I will present to you our work on Dr. Bert, a robust pre-trained model in French for biomedical and clinical domain. In this presentation, we first talk about language modeling in healthcare. Then we will present the main contribution of our article. The content is about ABC eval, a new approach for evaluating conversational AI. It was developed by the Emory NLP lab and Amazon Alexa AI. Instead of relying on human evaluation, ABC eval annotates model responses to measure various behaviors like irrelevant information, contradictions, etc. It was tested on four state - of - the - art chat models and found to be more reliable and predictive than existing methods. It can measure things like the proportion of turns with self - and partner - contradictions, which explain a significant amount of conversation quality. The results show that ABC eval can provide a higher - resolution evaluation of conversational AI than previous methods. It also quantifies challenges in the models, like common - sense violations and irrelevant information. The hope is that ABC eval can be used by others in the field to compare models more reliably. So, what do you think about this new approach?

The work presented by Chad Savan and his supervisor Nafisa at the University of Sheffield focuses on numerical reasoning. They aim to address the issue of models performing differently based on their size, with larger models generally performing better. However, they find that models with at least 10 billion parameters perform well, but those around 3 billion parameters, which are more accessible, perform poorly. The current benchmarks don't provide enough information about the models' mathematical abilities. To improve this, they introduce Fermat, a flexible evaluation set based on arithmetic types. Fermat includes math - worded questions extracted from Illinois Common Core, with numbers changed to mimic real - life scenarios. They also vary the numbers to test the models' range. Fermat has different axes for number understanding, mathematical operations, and training dependency. A baseline evaluation shows most models perform poorly across all aspects. Fine - tuning with math teachers' help improves performance across various aspects. Training dependency analysis shows that even when the exact expression is seen, the accuracy is still low, suggesting the importance of linguistic notions. The last investigation looks at the impact of training templates.

The work shares a dataset for language - guided floorplan generation. It focuses on the need for designs meeting requirements in natural language, different from less constrained generation like artwork. The dataset is constructed using publicly available floorplans and human - annotated language instructions from Amazon Mechanical Turk, totaling 5051 human - annotated and 76000 artificial instructions. The main challenges are strict constraints, understanding the big picture from fuzzy and tangled document - level text, and dealing with ambiguous, incomplete, or misleading human instructions.The method treats the task as a sequence - to - sequence problem under the encoder - decoder framework. It uses a transformer - based encoder - decoder structure initialized by a pre - trained language model, T5, for better language understanding. The objective is a normal language modeling task where the input is a set of instructions and the target is the bounding box sequence of rooms.

The English content mainly discusses the analysis of omission in dialogue summarization. It starts by introducing dialogue summarization as a subtask of text summarization, which aims to create a concise summary representing important information in a dialogue. It mentions that large - scale pretrained language models have made progress in generating fluent summaries, but they still have common errors like factual errors and omission. Omission is a major factor affecting the quality of dialogue summarization, leading to incomplete summaries. The study analyzed the omission rate of summaries from five domains and six pretrained models, finding that even state - of - the - art models have a high omission rate, around 70%. It also showed that omitted information is randomly distributed in dialogues. To better analyze and solve the omission problem, the work constructs a dataset called ODS, which provides high - quality omission labels for dialogue summarization. The dataset is built on five existing benchmarks and uses different models to generate diverse candidate summaries. An automatic method is proposed to produce omission labels, and human evaluation is also performed. Three frameworks are explored as baselines for omission detection, and the performance is evaluated using precision, recall, and F1 - score. The results show that the task is challenging. The paper presents a new dataset called Meeting QA for extractive question - answering on meeting transcripts. It highlights that millions of meetings worldwide generate vast amounts of transcripts, making this domain unique for NLP research. Previous works mainly focused on summarization and extracting action items, but Meeting QA addresses the lack of attention to the QA component in meeting discussions. The dataset is based on questions asked by participants and their corresponding answer sentences. It includes various interesting answer scenarios like multiple speakers contributing and multiple discontinuous sentences forming the answer span. The data collection process involves using public meeting transcripts from the AMI corpus and selecting questions based on punctuation. The dataset contains 7, 700 questions split into train, dev, and test sets. The paper also discusses the distribution of question types and the length distribution of meeting transcripts, questions, and answers. It shows that short context models perform slightly better than long context models in the fine - tuned setting, but multi - span models have comparable or slightly less performance than single - span models. In the zero - shot setting, there is a large gap between zero - shot performance and human performance, but silver data augmentation improves zero - shot performance.

Fredrik Riemenschneider is presenting on the intersection of NLP and classical philology. He talks about valuable resources for ancient Greek and Latin and the implications and challenges of multilinguality in large language models. He mentions several existing models like Latin BERT, Ancient Greek BERT, and another Ancient Greek BERT. These models are all BERT - encoder - only and monolingual. He then introduces their project of creating new language models specifically for classical philology. They have pre - trained two monolingual models for Ancient Greek, GriBERT and GREATER. They also developed multilingual models FilBERT and Filter, pretrained on Ancient Greek, Latin, and English data. They gathered pre - training data from Open Greek and Latin, Internet Archive, and other resources. For benchmarking, they used Universal Dependencies Treebanks for Greek and the EVA Latin 2022 dataset for Latin. Their models outperform the current state of the art for both languages. They also analyzed the behavior of GREATER's encoder and found that it behaves differently from native encoder - only models. Their models show strong performance in lemmatization.

The work focuses on resolving ambiguities in text - to - image generative models. It starts by curating a benchmark dataset with different types of ambiguities. Then, a prompt disambiguation framework is proposed. This framework can either ask clarifying questions from the user or generate different possible visual setups. After disambiguating the prompts, they are input into a text - to - image model to generate images. An automatic evaluation framework is also proposed to check if the generated images are faithful to the user's intention. The findings show that the framework has a positive effect on faithful generation and is in agreement with human evaluation. The work introduces a dialogue summarization method called SDDS. It aims to distill silent information from dialogue context into a concise summary. This is a challenging and interesting task in text summarization research. It helps people quickly capture highlights of semi - structured and multi - participant dialogues without reviewing complex dialogue contexts.The SDDS model has four main components. First, an utterance encoder encodes utterances into vector representations. Then, a static graph is constructed using existing dialogue structure modeling methods. A static - dynamic graph module combines multiple static graphs and captures semantic relationships between utterances based on their deep vector representations. Finally, a pre - trained language model is used as the summary generator to fuse static dialogue structure and dynamic learned dialogue structure into the final summary.To capture static dialogue structure information, four heuristic dialogue structure modeling methods are proposed. These include the discourse passing graph, which builds a dependency - based dialogue structure based on discourse passing tokens. A speaker relationship modeling method is also proposed to understand the fine - grained interaction between speakers. Position information of utterances is captured using relative distance as the edge feature of the utterance positional graph.

The content is about a work on dual cache for long document neural coreference resolution. Coreference resolution is about identifying and clustering mentions that refer to the same entity in a document. Conventional methods have quadratic complexity, but cache - based methods use a fixed - size cache to reduce it to linear. However, in long documents, topic shifts cause mentions to be scattered, leading to high cache misses with the LRU policy. The work proposes dual cache, with a local cache using LRU and a global cache using LFU. The model scans the document left - to - right, classifying mentions and adding them to the appropriate cache. Evaluation on benchmarks shows dual cache outperforms single cache methods, reducing cache misses and having a high performance - cost ratio. It's more cost - effective than single cache methods. If you have any questions about this, feel free to ask.

Hello everyone, I'm Makshita and today my coauthor Martin and I are presenting our work, the KitMUST, evaluating knowledge integration from multiple sources. This work is a collaboration between McGill University, Mila, and Microsoft Research. Natural language understanding models draw on a variety of knowledge sources, such as knowledge contained in their parameters, usually acquired by a pre-training, and knowledge given in inputs at inference time. Recent works in tasks like question answering show that models can use pretrain time knowledge to solve the task. But natural language understanding often requires knowledge that is also supplied at inference time. For example, in the sentence "John saw the newly elected president on TV", pretrain parameters can contain information about what presidents do and what a TV is, but they cannot reliably know who this instance specific entity John is or who the new president is, because the president might have changed since pretraining. Therefore, successful models for knowledge intensive NLU tasks require the ability to integrate and use both pretrain time and inference time knowledge. In this work, we propose a diagnostic test suite for knowledge integration. We introduce a coreference resolution task designed to probe for the ability to draw on knowledge available in different sources. We evaluate the dataset with human study participants and established coreference

The paper presents an approach to adaptive reasoning. It starts with a context, like Emily being stuck in traffic, and an outcome, like Emily making her flight. There are possible explanations given, such as her flight being delayed or leaving on time. The goal is to find a plausible explanation that bridges the gap between the context and outcome. The paper introduces an unsupervised learning method called LiPoR, which stands for Likelihood Learning with Posterior Regularization. This method treats explanations as a latent variable and aims to maximize the marginal likelihood of the outcome given the context. However, it also needs an additional regularizer to prefer plausible explanations. This regularizer enforces mutual exclusivity among explanations. The LiPoR objective has two parts: maximizing the likelihood of outcomes and preferring some explanations over others. The regularizer, denoted by Omega, takes the max between the entropy of P of Z given X, Y, and the log of M, where M is the number of plausible explanations. When the entropy is larger than the log of M, it means there are more than M explanations receiving probability mass, and in that case, the entropy of P of Z given X, Y is minimized to prefer a subset of explanations.

The audio introduces a new divide - and - conquer learning framework for image retrieval from linguistically complex text. It addresses the challenge of highly similar images and long descriptions. Traditional methods like visual language models perform well on image - sentence retrieval but struggle with complex texts. The framework is inspired by divide - and - conquer strategy and dual - process theory. It uses a proposition generator to break down complex propositions into simple ones, a visual - linguistic interactor for visual - propositional interaction, and a neural symbolic reasoner as system 2 to integrate reasoning states and results. The method outperforms baselines and is process - interpretable. It suggests that neural symbolic calculation could improve large language models' compositional reasoning and planning ability. Divide - and - conquer is compared to self - asking to decompose complex reasoning into simple problems.

The paper presents a study on prompting for machine translation using a 540 million parameter language model called Palm. The fairness of a downstream NLP model is defined by how it performs on different political leanings. If it performs well across all political leanings, it's considered fair. For example, in hate speech detection, a left-leaning language model should be good at detecting hate speech targeting socially minority groups, and a right-leaning one should be good at detecting hate speech targeting more powerful groups. This way, it avoids marginalizing people with opposite political opinions. So, it's about the model's performance being unbiased across different political perspectives. The content discusses a method for improving theory of mind reasoning in large language models. It introduces the Sally - Anne test as an example of a theory of mind task. The method, called Symbolic Tom, uses graphical representations to model characters' beliefs. It computes these graphs for different characters and combinations up to a predefined level. The graphs are used to answer questions about characters' beliefs. Experiments show that Symbolic Tom outperforms baseline models like a fine - tuned GPT - 3 model and Textual Time Travel in theory of mind reasoning tasks. It achieves performance gains across different models and datasets. The method also generalizes well to new story structures and linguistic variations.

This paper introduces a work on distinguishing script knowledge from large language models for constrained language planning. It focuses on planning for goals with specific constraints, unlike previous work which mainly dealt with abstract goals of stereotypical activities. The authors define the problem of constrained language planning, which involves different constraints on planning goals. They evaluate and improve the constrained language planning ability of large language models. To acquire specific goals, they extend abstract goals with multifaceted constraints and use InstructGPT to generate scripts. They find that all large language models perform unsatisfactorily on planning for specific goals. Detailed analysis reveals that while the semantic completeness of generated scripts is acceptable, faithfulness to constraints cannot be guaranteed. They then propose an over - generated then filter method to improve generation quality. This method involves showing constraint types to InstructGPT, over - generating scripts, and using a filter model to select faithful scripts. The authors also introduce a dataset named CoScript for constrained language planning, which is generated from large language models using symbolic knowledge distillation. This dataset is used to ensure the quality of validation and test sets through crowd - sourced workers. The abstract shows that CoScript has a high constraint distribution, indicating its potential for further research in constrained language planning.

Hi, I'm Myra, and today I'll be talking about our paper "Marked Personas: Using Natural Language Prompts to Measure Stereotypes in Language Models." This work is done in collaboration with Essin Dermush and Dan Jurafsky.In recent years, many have documented the prevalence of social bias and stereotypes in large language models, or LLMs. However, these measures have various limitations. They usually rely on hand - constructed datasets that are very time - consuming to curate, and they also usually only measure very specific stereotypes, meaning that they don't generalize well to other demographics or contexts, or they simply capture very general, broad associations like negative associations with particular groups.Furthermore, most work in this space doesn't account for intersectionality, which is the notion that multifaceted social identities can compound biases and be unique loci of harm.To overcome these limitations, we rely on the property that these newer instruction - tuned LLMs are very good at responding to instructions and prompts. So we can ask the model to generate a persona, which is a depiction of an imagined individual, using a prompt like "Imagine you are an Asian woman, describe yourself." And we can immediately see that this is very generalizable to any demographic,

The presentation is about a new optimizer called CAM for large language model training. It aims to balance fast convergence and low memory usage. It introduces NMF as a preliminary, which reduces memory requirements from O, MN, to O, M + N. However, NMF - based AdFactor has errors in training deep neural networks and converges slowly compared to Adam. The presentation then shows how to handle erroneous updates in the ideal case. It proposes an approach to decrease the side effect of inaccurate updates by using the residual between MT and UT as the instability in the preserved momentum. Experiments on BookCorpus and English Wikipedia show that CAM outperforms Adam and AdFactor in terms of validation accuracy and training efficiency for large models. It achieves a 3.4% increase in validation accuracy compared to AdFactor with the same number of training steps. CAM also performs better than Adam in pre - training for large models with a huge reduction in memory cost.

The work introduces a framework called ROHT for explainable question answering. It focuses on hierarchical question decomposition. There are two main challenges: determining the granularity of question decomposition and finding the optimal solution among possible ones. ROHT is a two - stage framework. First, it builds a hierarchical question decomposition tree, HQDT, for a complex question. Then, it does probabilistic reasoning over the HQDT. The HQDT is built by using a question decomposer for leaf nodes and a question generator for intermediate questions. Certainty scores are computed for each node. ROHT is evaluated on two datasets, KQA - Pro and Music. On KQA - Pro, ROHT outperforms existing KB - QA methods when only using the incomplete KB. Adding Wikipedia as a supplementary text corpus further improves ROHT's performance compared to ROHT - KB. This shows the benefits of integrating answers from different knowledge sources.

The content discusses how political biases in pre - training data of language models can lead to unfairness in downstream tasks. It mentions that large - scale web - crawled data, including political news media, are well - covered in language model training. This creates a mixed blessing. On one hand, diverse perspectives are learned, celebrating democracy. On the other hand, social biases in different political opinions can cause fairness issues.Investigating the political bias propagation pipeline is proposed. They evaluate language models' political leanings using political questionnaires like the Political Compass test. Preliminary results show language models have varying political leanings, with GPT - 4 being the most liberal. They also conduct controlled experiments by further pre - training on partisan corpora to see how political biases are picked up. The ideological coordinates of language models shift accordingly. They also look into whether language models pick up societal polarization. When evaluated on hate speech and fake news detection, left - leaning models are better at detecting hate speech targeting socially minority groups but worse at targeting more powerful groups. Right - leaning models are better at detecting hate speech targeting white and men but worse at targeting black, LGBTQ+, and other minority communities. This indicates a pressing fairness issue regarding language model political biases.

The talk discusses different dependency structures in coordination. Universal Dependencies and Egor Milchuk's theory assume the first conjunct is the head. The plug approach in plug dependency treebanks has the conjunction as the head. The multi - headed approach in the cut - sons word grammar has all conjuncts as heads. The aim is to argue for symmetric structures against asymmetric ones. The argument is based on the principle of dependency length minimization. In English, direct objects prefer to be close to the verb, but this can be ameliorated if the direct object is heavy and long. The paper extracts statistics from the enhanced Penn Treebank and confirms that left conjuncts tend to be shorter when the governor is on the left and absent. This tendency grows with the length difference between conjuncts. However, when the governor is on the right, the effect disappears.

Simultaneous speech translation, or Simo ST, is the process of translating spoken language into text in another language in real - time, enabling cross - language communication. Current Simo ST models have problems like specific architectures being trained, long and complicated training procedures, and training multiple models for different latency regimes. Our solution is to use existing offline ST models without retraining or adapting specific architectures. We use only one model for every latency regime and handle latency through specific parameters. We leverage the knowledge acquired by the model through the attention mechanism between audio input and text output, the cross - attention mechanism. Our solution is to propose a dot or encoder - decoder attention strategy. We decide whether to emit or not a partial translation based on where attention points to. A word is emitted if the attention is not concentrated, that is, the sum is below a certain threshold alpha towards the last lambda speech frames, meaning the received information is enough stable. For example, if we receive a speech chunk containing "I'm going to talk about" and our model predicts the translation in German, we look at the cross - attention weights. Task - oriented prompts were used to guide the model, and a disentanglement loss was introduced. The model was based on the dialogue GPT framework with a compositional prompt module.

The domain - attentive highlighting model achieves the best performance on final and preserves the generalization capability. The methods can also benefit unseen relations and mismatch pairs.

The audio discusses the current challenges in language model research, particularly the lack of grounding during pre - training. It mentions that most language models, including large - scale ones, are pre - trained on text corpora without grounding. This gap between pre - training and downstream applications makes grounding language understanding difficult. Existing research often uses language models to directly generate plans, but these plans may not always be grammatical or valid. The speaker proposes a new framework called Pangu, which focuses on discrimination instead of generation. A symbolic agent proposes candidate plans, and a language model scores and ranks them. This approach separates the neural world from the symbolic world, making it easier for language models to handle. The framework is tested on large - base question - answering tasks and shows strong performance across different settings and language models. It also demonstrates good sample efficiency.

The content is about a joint work on detecting improvable claims for argumentative writing support. It starts by introducing text revisions as an essential part of professional writing, especially in argumentative writing where finding the right words is crucial for effective communication. The authors present a revision process of an argumentative claim, like "cell phones cause brain cancer, " showing how it can be refined. The paper focuses on how to determine if an argumentative claim is phrased well enough. It introduces two tasks: suboptimal claim detection and claim improvement suggestion. The authors explore challenges in working with revision - based data, such as different domains having different goals and notions of quality. They specifically focus on argumentative texts and model the quality of these texts based on implicit revision patterns from collaborative online debate platforms. They identify four main challenges: representativity and reliability, model complexity and architecture, contextual dependence of argument quality dimensions, and topical and user bias. These challenges arise from the nature of revision - based corpora and the notion of argument quality.

The video introduces a new benchmark dataset called MeetingBank. It addresses the need for high - quality meeting summaries and reliable resources for public meetings. Data collection involves using speech - to - text conversion, identifying meeting details, locating reference summaries, and aligning timestamps. The audio discusses a paper on human - in - the - loop evaluation for early misinformation detection, specifically about COVID - 19 treatments. It points out that existing approaches for detecting misinformation on social media platforms have two main flaws. Firstly, they are unrealistically evaluated, using retrospectively constructed datasets instead of live data, and there's a risk of leaked counter - evidence. Secondly, they are not human - centric, not representing the real scale or noisiness of platforms, and often cut out humans from the misinformation detection process. The paper proposes an evaluation framework for systems that address these issues, aiming to be end - to - end and have well - integrated human feedback. It also presents a novel workflow for COVID - 19 treatment misinformation, with two main components: detecting misleading claims and policy violation verification. The system has a precision of 65% in detecting policy violations.

The work presents a two - step pipeline for finding high - agreement Amazon Mechanical Turk workers. It starts with qualification settings, including a pre - task qualification for location, number of HITS, and approval rate. The first qualification task tests annotators' ability to evaluate multiple dimensions correctly, categorizing them into gold, silver, bronze, and block. Only gold and silver workers pass. The second stage is an endurance task testing capacity for handling heavy workload. The reference - based task checks general performance on true annotation tasks. The pipeline results in 4 gold and 8 silver workers out of 200 participants. It serves as a best practice for high - agreement annotation at large scale and lower cost, avoiding resources wasted on discarded annotations.

The paper introduces a new task called KG - based fact verification. Existing datasets like FEVER and VITAMIN C use Wikipedia text or tables as evidence, but none use knowledge graphs with natural language claims. The authors propose a new dataset, FKG, for KG - based fact verification. The knowledge graph used is DBpedia, and claims are in two styles: written and colloquial. There are two labels: supported and refuted. The task involves retrieving evidence from DBpedia and verifying the claim using the evidence. Five types of reasoning are used: one - hop, conjunction, existence, multi - hop, and negation. For example, one - hop claims can be verified by checking if two entities in the claim are connected by a relation. The dataset includes claims in both styles for practical use. Two methods were used: the colloquial style transfer model and presupposition templates. The dataset has some statistics, and baselines were constructed in two ways. This new task and dataset aim to improve fact verification in the context of knowledge graphs.

The presentation is about a joint work on unsupervised case retrieval using event extraction. The work aims to help legal professionals like lawyers and judges find relevant past precedents in a challenging time of increasing case volume.The key contributions are the ILBCR dataset and the Ukraine pipeline. The ILBCR dataset is a benchmark for PCR tasks, containing 7,070 legal cases with an average of 6.775 citations per query document. It has a larger pool of cases, longer documents, a larger vocabulary, and more citations compared to the existing Koli 21 dataset.The Ukraine pipeline uses unsupervised learning and an event - based approach. It shows high retrieval efficiency, low inference time, and generalization across Indian and Canadian legal systems without specific tuning. Event extraction is crucial, using dependency parsing with Spacy to represent case documents as a collection of events. The event extraction block has three steps: preprocessing, dependency parsing, and post - processing. Interaction matrices are computed between query and candidate events for ranking candidates. Various models were experimented with, including count - based, transformer - based, and event - based models. Transformer - based models performed worse than baseline methods, while event - based models showed promise.

Mario is presenting his work "Disorder: A double domain adaptation model for detecting signs of mental disorders in social media". It's a group effort from Mexico and Spain. He defines mental disorders as psychological syndromes causing distress and disability. There are types like major depression, PTSD, bulimia, and anorexia. Social media is a huge source for research on mental health issues. His work aims to detect mental health disorders by analyzing social media posts automatically. This could support a new technology to warn about mental disorders and provide evidence. Domain adaptation is used because of insufficient annotated data. They start with a base language model and integrate information from Reddit and mental health. They also use a lexicon to guide the masking process. The results on the ARIS datasets show good balance. The model focuses on important words related to mental disorders. It generates more negative and psychological oriented words compared to a base model. The most important sequences of text are visualized using a graph.

The research focuses on document - level distant relation extraction. Previous methods relied on large - scale human - annotated corpora, which are time - consuming and labor - intensive. Recent work used distant - supervised data to pre - train models for better performance. However, DS data has noisy labels. The paper proposes a framework with uncertainty - guided label denoising. It first trains a pre - denoising model with both DS and human - annotated data to generate pseudo - labels. Uncertainty estimation is introduced to determine the trustworthiness of model predictions. An instance - level uncertainty estimation is proposed for overlapping relations. A relabeled strategy with dynamic class uncertainty threshold and a multi - phase training strategy is designed to boost performance. Uncertainty estimation is important for misclassification detection, out - of - distribution instance detection, and active learning. The paper modifies the estimation process to obtain instance - level uncertainty scores for each positive pseudo - label. Dynamic class uncertainty thresholds are proposed to filter pseudo - labels with high uncertainty. The original DS label is replaced with pseudo - labels that have lower uncertainty scores. A multi - phase training strategy is designed to fully utilize DS data and improve the DCR model's performance.

The work presented is about cross - lingual semantic parsing in multiple natural languages and meaning representations. It aims to translate queries in different languages into various representations like SQL, lambda calculus, and FunQL. Existing models have limitations like lack of coverage on certain languages or representations. The proposed Exemplar provides a unified dataset for cross - lingual semantic parsing in multiple languages and representations. It has 9 datasets, 5 tasks, 8 million representations, and 22 languages in 15 language families. Six training and evaluation settings are considered, including translate test, monolingual model, monolingual few - shot, multilingual model, cross - lingual zero - shot, and cross - lingual few - shot transfer. Encoder - decoder models perform best on all datasets. The cross - lingual performance gap is significant in zero - shot transfer but narrows in few - shot transfer. Encoder - decoder outperforms previous work.

The work focuses on mitigating label biases in in - context learning. It starts by identifying three types of label biases: vanilla label bias, context label bias, and domain label bias. The domain label bias is a new type that captures the effect of the task corpus on model predictions. Experiments show that the task corpus can bias model predictions, with in - domain words from the corpus showing preference over random English words. The model performs well on tasks with small domain label bias but struggles on those with large bias. To handle these biases, domain context calibration is proposed. It uses random in - domain words from the task corpus to estimate and calibrate the model's biases, improving in - context learning performance, especially on tasks with large domain label bias.

The paper presents a novel task called Transferable Audio - Visual Text Generation. It addresses the challenges of multimodal text generation, especially for audio - visual tasks, like the difficulty in data annotation and the domain shift between visual and audio content.For the framework, it includes an Audio - Visual Meta - Map Network, an encoder - generator, and a Contrastive Learning approach. The Audio - Visual Meta - Map Network maps visual concepts to a unified auditory semantic space. It uses a set of learnable tokens called visual prefixes for audio clusters to improve the semantic alignment. The encoder - generator uses an alpha - tuning mechanism to evaluate the contribution of different modalities. Contrastive Learning is used to train the model, with a loss function and meta - learning details.The experimental section builds two benchmarks based on MS - VTT and MS - BD for cross - dataset and cross - domain settings. The results show that the proposed approach outperforms state - of - the - art methods in transferable audio - visual text generation.

Ananya and Vineet presented their work on IndicMTEval, a dataset for evaluating machine translation metrics for Indian languages. They focused on five languages: Tamil, Malayalam, Hindi, Marathi, and Gujarati. They selected 200 sentences from the FLORES dataset and generated candidate translations for each. Seven translation models were used, resulting in 1400 candidate translations per language. They collected human annotations on 7000 samples, with bilingual expert annotators evaluating the outputs. Error types were classified into accuracy, fluency, and special category errors. They found that newer models like NLLB and IndicTrans had fewer errors compared to older models like CBIT. The best performing models on average were IndicTrans, NLLB, Google API, Bing API, MT5, CBIT, and NMT. Metrics like CHRF had the highest correlation across languages, but embedding - based metrics like LaBSE and BERT score with multi - lingual models showed better correlations. Cometscore variants had the highest overall correlations. Splitting the dataset by error types showed that accuracy - based errors had higher correlations with human scores.
