The "marked words" method draws upon the sociolinguistic concept of markedness. It identifies words that distinguish marked groups from unmarked ones. It uses weighted log odds ratios to distinguish the top words for each marked group. For instance, for the persona of a black woman, it compares the log odds ratios against both white personas and man personas.
The authors are affiliated with the University of Washington.

The work introduces a level - attention - based coordination - multi - modal fusion framework for emotion regulation in conversations. It aims to predict the emotion label of each utterance in a dialogue, considering text, audio, and visual modalities. Existing methods focus on speaker and contextual information but lack in fully utilizing multimodal information. The proposed framework, Multi - emo, has four key components: unimodal feature extraction, context modeling, multimodal fusion, and emotion classification. It proposes Vis - ext - net for visual feature extraction, Multi - attend for multimodal fusion, and a sample - weighted focal contrastive loss to address minority emotion classes and semantically similar emotions. Extensive experiments on Meld and IEMO CAP show state - of - the - art performance. The contributions include Vis - ext - net, Multi - attend, and the sample - weighted focal contrastive loss.

The work titled "When does translation require context? A data - driven multilingual exploration" by Coyote and collaborators explores how context affects translation. It shows that words like "mole" can have different meanings depending on context, like a spy or a birthmark. Context - dependent translations are hard to evaluate with corpus - level metrics like BLEU. The work measures how much a word depends on context using p - CXMI, which can be applied at the sentence or word level. They analyze words with high p - CXMI in TED - talk transcripts translated into 14 languages. They find patterns, like dual pronouns in Arabic needing context. The work designs a benchmark for document - level translation, using a multilingual discourse - aware tagger to identify context - dependent phenomena. When evaluated with different metrics, context - aware models perform better than context - agnostic ones. This shows that corpus - level metrics alone can't determine the best document - level translation system.

The work presented at SL 2023 focuses on nonparallel story author style transfer at the discourse level. It addresses the challenge of transferring style - specific contents between different styles, which is crucial for emulating author style. The main challenge is in imitating the author's linguistic choices at the discourse level. The proposed solution is a generation model called Style Trans, which learns discourse representations from the source text and combines them with normal style embeddings to generate text in the target style. A new training objective is also designed to reduce style - specific features from the discourse representations. The training framework is separated into two stages. The first stage uses an adversarial training framework with self - reconstruction loss, disentanglement loss, sentence order loss, and style classifier loss. The second stage aims to fill in the correct style - specific contents and remove masked tokens. Extensive experiments on Chinese and English datasets show that the model outperforms strong baselines in terms of style control and content preservation. The transfer texts are also aligned with the golden texts in the style feature space.
Universal Dependencies.

The paper presents a new model, FFUIE, for universal information extraction. It addresses the ambiguity in current spam - based UIE models by proposing fuzzy spam boundaries instead of precise ones. It also adapts the attention mechanism for spam extraction to be adaptive rather than static. The model represents the target boundary as a continuous distribution of correct probability. It uses BCE loss and KL divergence to guide the model. A fuzzy spam attention layer is added to trim the attention distribution. Experiments on three tasks show significant performance improvements. FFUIE achieves new SOTA results on relationship extraction and ASDE tasks. It demonstrates better generalization capabilities and utilizes annotation information fully. The visualization of the attention distribution shows the model focuses on semantic information within a limited range of preceding tokens.

The work focuses on factuality error correction for dialogue summarization. It presents two main solutions. One is introducing factuality - related objectives during training or inference to make summarization models more faithful. The other is designing a factuality error correction model, FEC, which is independent of the summarization model. FEC takes the source document and model - generated summary as input and outputs a corrected summary.The current FEC models are evaluated using factuality metrics like FactCC and DAE. However, there are flaws in this evaluation method. First, factuality metrics give an overall score which may not be reliable. Second, this evaluation blurs the line between the two types of solutions, allowing FEC models to generate different summaries without error correction.The work argues that manually annotated reference correction is necessary to address these issues. It proposes a new taxonomy of factuality errors, with content - based and form - based classifications. The evaluation framework is built on the basis of ERRANT, an evaluation metric for grammar error correction. It mainly consists of alignment, classification, and comparison steps. Experiments with different training modes show that training FEC models with reference summaries from dialogue summarization datasets yields the best results on reliable factuality metrics. There is an urgent need to change the evaluation method for FEC models.

Hello, my name is Kyo Yen and I will be presenting our work titled "When does translation require context? A data - driven multilingual exploration." This work was done in collaboration with Patrick Pronounce, Emile, Andre F. T. Martins, and Graham Neubig.So a lot of translations depend on context. For example, how would we translate "mole" in this sentence? Well, if the previous sentence was "Things could start to get dangerous if the ministers find out," then "mole" refers to a spy. But if the previous sentence was "Could it be anything serious, doctor?" then "mole" refers to a birthmark. So depending on context, the meaning of the word changes and therefore its translation changes as well.However, evaluating how well models can translate cases like those is pretty hard. Firstly, because only a small portion of translations depend on context, which makes corpus - level metrics like BLEU unable to capture these translations. And some people have suggested targeted evaluation on context - dependent translations, but these resources only support limited types of context - dependent translations and limited sets of languages, since they usually rely on domain knowledge and human curation.In this work, we try to answer these two questions. Hi welcome to our presentation of Dplane a new corpus for German text simplification on the document level and on the sentence level My name is Regina Stöten and I will guide you through the first part of the presentation Let's first define text simplification Text simplification is a process of adapting a text to improve the text comprehension of it for a specific target group as people with reading problems or non-native speakers To train a text simplification model we require parallel pairs of texts for example of documents or sentences And the example here you can see a parallel aligned sentence pair of a complex German sentence and its today translation into plain language To simplify the sentence different techniques are possible as you can see in the example such as lexical substitution clause deletion clause deletion reordering or insertion of words We now propose our new corpus Dplane because in the recent years there were some problems with existing corpora So for example these corpora here are too small to train a text simplification model on The other three models which are proposed in recent years are all automatically aligned which means they can be error prone in their alignments Therefore we propose our new corpus Dplane which is split into two sub corpora Dplane - apa and Dplane - web Dplane - apa is based on news texts in Dplane - apa

Hi and I'm going to talk about our work on resolving indirect referring expressions for entity selection in which we introduce the L - entities corpus. And my name is Javad Hosseini and this is a joint work with Filip Radlinski, Silvia Parodi and Ali Louis.Our goal is to understand users' language when they want to make a choice. Consider this alternative question: "Did you mean 'Easy on Me' or 'I Got a Feeling'?" Here a user wants to select between one of these two songs.The most obvious thing is to use a direct reference, for example by saying the name of the song, "Easy on Me", or its position, "the first one". But sometimes an indirect reference is more appropriate to have a more natural conversation. This could happen when the user cannot remember the name of the song, or the pronunciations are too similar to each other and hard to disambiguate, or when the user wants to specify a preference.Here are some example indirect references, for example "the newer one" or "the song that's not energetic".This is an important problem in conversational systems and also for benchmarking N - M entity understanding.We're not aware of a public data set, a large - scale public data

The audio is about a work by Valerio Basile presenting a collaboration between the University of Turin and Amazon Alexa on natural language understanding and processing. It focuses on irony detection, a difficult task for modern models. They developed the English Perspective Irony Corpus, EPIC, collecting data from social media sources like Reddit and Twitter over a one - and - a - half - year period. They used Prolific for crowdsourcing annotations from 74 annotators, each given 200 texts. The annotation interface was simple, resembling a chat interface. They observed differences in inter - annotator agreement depending on how they divided the annotators by gender, age group, nationality, etc. They built perspective - aware models by finetuning a pre - trained language model on different annotator splits. These models showed more confidence in their predictions compared to gold - standard aggregated models.

Dog whistles are coded rhetoric that can be interpreted differently by in - and out - groups. For example, "cosmopolitan" can be a dog whistle for Jewish people. This study developed a glossary of over 340 terms, especially for racist, transphobic, and antisemitic dog whistles. It also did a case study on historical US political speeches, finding a pattern of increased use of racial dog whistles since the Civil Rights era. The study evaluated dog whistle recognition in language models like GPT - 3, which could surface many dog whistles but performed poorly with informal and social media - used ones. It also showed how dog whistles can evade content moderation by being rated less toxic when replacing slurs and standard group labels. Overall, this project aims to better understand and study dog whistles in language and politics.

Well, the findings that led to the conclusion that temporal drift is the main cause of performance loss were that when they retrained or continued to pretrain some models with more recent data, the performance degraded with larger temporal gap. This confirmed their hypothesis that the main cause of the performance drop is temporal drift. So, yeah, that's the key finding. If you have any other questions about this, feel free to ask.

The work aims to improve the robustness of NLI models by addressing the issue of learning and using shortcuts. It proposes a minimax training method. The key idea is to focus on underrepresented hard examples that counteract the use of shortcuts in dominant easy examples. The method doesn't assume the type of shortcuts in the dataset and relies on the learner's own training dynamics to generate example weights. It uses a feed - forward network for the auxiliary. The method is evaluated on three NLI datasets and their adversarial tests. Compared to an ERM - trained model and the best - performing shortcut mitigation method, the minimax training objective consistently improves out - of - distribution performance while maintaining high in - distribution accuracy. The work also examines if the performance improvements transfer to larger models and synthetic shortcuts and out - of - domain tests. It also conducts a qualitative evaluation of the learned example weight distribution. If you have any questions or thoughts about this, feel free to share.

Interactive dictation is a process where users dictate and edit documents using voice in a natural way. It allows users to correct themselves during dictation and issue verbal commands for edits. The work introduces this task, formalizes it as a four - step procedure, designs a data collection interface, builds a dataset, and creates a baseline system. The system includes an ASR recognition module, a command extraction and normalization module, and a command execution module. The data collection involves users dictating and issuing commands, with the system collecting the trajectories. A baseline system is trained to perform each step of the process.

Hi everyone, I'm Jenny, a first-year PhD student at Carnegie Mellon University, and today I'll be presenting your work on "NL Positionality: Characterizing Design Biases in Datasets and Models." This work was done in collaboration with some folks at the University of Washington and the Allen Institute for AI, namely Sebastian Santi, Ronan Le Bras, Katerina Rynke, and Martin Sap. So let's start off by imagining that you're working for a newspaper and you're sifting through comments under your news article, trying to remove toxic content. You might turn towards a popular API like Perspective API for toxicity detection, and this works really well if you're Carl Jones, where Perspective API is able to detect correctly toxic instances. But that's not really the case for Dithia Sharma, where Perspective API is really not as sensitive to offensive terms that are more common in Indian contexts. This is an example of a design bias, where we see systematic performance differences of technology between populations. Design biases like the one that we just saw before might occur due to the positionality of the NLP researchers and model developers. Minimal-pair unacceptable inputs are inputs that are not acceptable in the minimal-pair paradigm. They are used to evaluate language models on acceptability judgments.

The audio discusses weakly supervised learning, WSL. It explains that in WSL, data is labeled using weak sources like simple rules or low - quality crowdsourcing, which are cheaper but noisy. Directly training on weakly labeled data can lead to memorizing label noise and poor generalization. The audio then presents research findings on WSL. It shows that clean validation samples are necessary for WSL to work well, with a large performance drop without them. Increasing the number of clean validation samples helps WSL performance. Direct fine - tuning on clean data can outperform WSL approaches, especially when there are only 10 samples per class. This suggests that complex WSL methods aren't always necessary.

The audio discusses entity tracking in language models. It explains that for an agent to understand discourse, it needs to track entities and their state changes. For example, in a recipe, an agent should understand how ingredients end up in a bowl and then become part of the batter. The research aims to find out how well large language models can track entities. Challenges in designing an evaluation task include preventing models from using pre - training data patterns, predicting entity states from individual words, and memorizing entity state sequences. The task involves boxes and objects, with the model predicting contents after state - changing operations. The experiments show that most models just repeat the initial state, but Text - Da Vinci - 03 has non - trivial tracking. GPT - 3.5 models trained on code also exhibit this ability.
The authors used multiple public and private downstream tasks such as named entity recognition, classification, part-of-speech tagging, and question answering.

The work presented is about characterizing design biases in datasets and models. It was done in collaboration with researchers from the University of Washington and the Allen Institute for AI. The example given is about a toxicity detection API not being sensitive to certain offensive terms in Indian contexts. Positionality, the perspectives of NLP researchers and model developers, is discussed. It can influence research outcomes. The study aims to compare datasets and models with real users through a framework called NL Positionality. This framework involves re-annotating datasets with diverse annotators and comparing their annotations to models and datasets using a Pearson's r correlation score. The study used Lab in the Wild, an online crowdsourcing platform, to recruit diverse volunteers. Over 16, 000 annotations from 1, 000 annotators from 87 countries were collected. The study found that there is positionality in NLP datasets and models.

MultiInstruct is the first multimodal instruction tuning benchmark dataset. It consists of 62 diverse multimodal tasks covering 10 broad categories, derived from 21 existing open source datasets, and each task is equipped with 5 expert written instructions. It aims to investigate multimodal instruction tuning on a multimodal dataset, which is different from other benchmarks that mainly focus on language - only tasks.

The English content is about a work titled "CodeIE: Large Code Generation Model for Better Few - Shot Information Extractors" by Peng Li from Fudan University. It discusses information extraction, a classic NLP task, and how previous models using pre - trained language models like T5 and GPT - 3 had issues with mismatched outputs during inference. The proposed CodeIE transforms the text - to - structure information extraction task into a structure - to - structure code generation task. For named entity recognition, a prompt is designed to guide the model to output code. Evaluation on three recognition datasets and four relation extraction datasets shows that CodeIE outperforms traditional baseline models like UIE and T5. The analysis reveals that CodeIE aligns better with the information extraction task and has fewer structural errors compared to using GPT - 3.

Enrico is presenting at ACL 23 about what a text classifier learns about morality. He explains that morality is what helps distinguish right from wrong, our internal compass. It's essential for society and language models should understand it in text. The NLP community has approached this but often treats it as a binary scale between immoral and moral. However, morality is subjective, with different people labeling the same concept differently. For example, abortion can be seen as immoral or moral by different people. The Moral Foundation Theory suggests there are five different ways humans perceive morality, like taste buds. Language models can somewhat understand morality in text, and Enrico's paper aims to understand what they learn. They use the Mora Foundation Twitter Corpus to study how morality is expressed differently across domains like All Lives Matter and Black Lives Matter. Language models recognize that subversion is associated with different words in these domains.

The paper discusses a method for Compsense QA. It aims to retrieve relevant knowledge from an external service using language models and knowledge base. Previous works combined knowledge stored in BERT language models and knowledge base to solve Compsense QA. However, they had issues like introducing irrelevant entities and limited interaction between models. The proposed method, DHLK, builds a HKG based on multiple knowledge bases. It uses a two - stage pre - training strategy and KRL to optimize the structure and knowledge distribution of HKG. The language model encodes and fuses the prompt list. It removes sub - words of the precise entity and retrieves key entities' relations. It uses RoBERTa and Mask - Self - Attention to encode and fuse QA context and entities in HKG. It dynamically removes entities with weak relevance. For initial entity and relation embeddings, it gets them by mean - pooling. It introduces TransE to optimize embeddings. It applies attention to model sub - graphs and incorporates relations into Mask - Self - Attention. It updates embeddings by L - layers of R - MSA. Finally, it gets the graph embedding of HKG and incorporates it into QA context for better prediction.

Cognitive dissonance is two beliefs or actions that are inconsistent. For example, a person who knows cigarettes could kill them but still smokes. It's important to study in language because it's a common phenomenon in daily decision making.

The work presented is about a new vision - language model architecture called Magic Tower. It aims to improve the ability of AI systems to understand both images and text. The goal of vision - language learning is to train a smart AI that can handle both modalities. Visual question answering is a key task in this area. Recent progress in vision - language models has been made through large - scale self - supervised pre - training on image - text pairs and transformer - based models.The two - tower architecture is a common model structure, consisting of text and visual encoders and a cross - model encoder. However, existing unimodal encoders in this architecture only feed the last - layer representation directly to the cross - model encoder, ignoring the semantic knowledge at different layers. Magic Tower addresses this by connecting multiple top unimodal layers in a layer - by - layer fashion, allowing for the exploitation of different levels of unimodal semantic knowledge. It has two main advantages over previous models. First, it can effectively utilize different unimodal layer representations, which was a limitation in previous models. Second, it is more scalable and capable as the number of cross - model layers is not tied to the number of unimodal layer representations used. Magic Tower has achieved superior performance on various downstream

This work presents a method for generating structured pseudo labels for zero-shot video sentence localization. It focuses on zero-shot video sentence localization, which aims to find relevant video segments given a natural language query. The existing methods require manual annotation, which is costly and inefficient. This paper proposes a noise - resistant structured pseudo label generation method. It uses a pre - trained image caption model to generate more complex pseudo queries. Then, a model measures the relevance between video frames and pseudo queries to generate pseudo events. It reduces the weight of noisy samples and corrects noisy labels to reduce the influence of label noise. Experiments on two datasets show its effectiveness.

The audio is about a work on injecting key knowledge in nearest neighbor machine translation. It starts by acknowledging collaborators. The work focuses on neural machine translation, where the goal is to learn a generalized representation space. However, neural networks often create a non - smooth space, limiting generalization. Low - frequency tokens are dispersed sparsely in the MT model's representation space, leading to poor performance in certain areas.To enhance performance, the work proposes a solution called KNMT. It aims to smooth predictions based on nearest neighbors in the representation space. This requires a training corpus to build a key - value data store. At each decoding step, the MT model queries the data store to retrieve nearest entries and refine prediction probabilities.However, this approach has drawbacks like time - consuming retrieval and immovable representations. To overcome these, the framework INK is proposed. It has two steps: first, key knowledge is extracted from the data store to guide the adapter to adjust representations, then updated representations are used to refresh the data store asynchronously. The training loop runs until convergence. The framework optimizes the adapter with a combined learning objective. Experiments show that INK outperforms the state - of - the - art KNMT system and achieves the best performance after smoothing the representation space. The

Hi my name is Adam Skorokowski and this talk is about the dependency structure of coordination. As you may know that different dependency structures are assumed by different theories and corpus approaches. So for example in the universal dependencies the structure of the coordinate coordination Lisa Bart and Maggie is such that the first conjunct is the head of the whole coordinate structure. So in this case Lisa. Similar approach is assumed in Igor Milchuk's meaning text theory where again the whole coordinate structure is headed by the first conjunct. So these two approaches are symmetric right they they single out one of the conjuncts. Now there are also symmetric approaches to coordinate coordinate structures such as the Prague approach the conjunction headed approach assumed in Prague dependency treebanks where coordinate structures are headed by the conjunction. So we get some dependencies from and to all the conjuncts. And finally there's also a multi - headed approach that's used for example in the cut - sons word grammar where so to say all conjuncts are heads of the coordinate structures. So we get dependencies from the governor here loves to all conjuncts separately Lisa Bart and Maggie. Cross-lingual transfer is the task of training a model on one source language and then using it to perform tasks in another language. It's like teaching a model in one language and then asking it to do the same thing in another language. If you want to know more about it, feel free to ask me.

The speech is about a research on handling out - of - vocabulary words, OOVs, in embedding - based downstream models. It starts by acknowledging the difficulty in representing OOVs but their importance. The researchers observe word formation and associate OOVs with relevant words to infer their meaning. They develop a neural approach using a word relationship graph. Each word or word piece is a node in the graph, and its embedding is a node feature. They preserve all nodes in the first layer for complete word piece information and sample a fixed number of nodes in the second layer to mitigate noise. A graph neural network processes the word relationship graph. They use a self - attention network to assign attributes to OOV nodes based on characters. Two levels of graph attention network concatenate and fuse the initial input with the higher embedding of each layer. A residual block refines the graph - level representation. They apply contrastive learning in the loss function to encourage proximity between relevant words and push OOVs further apart. Extensive experiments show the model outperforms baselines in intrinsic and extrinsic tasks, benefiting static and contextual models. The model has potential for other languages, especially agglutinative languages which form words by combining morphemes, but is more challenging for fusional languages.

The research presented by Bing Shen aims to evaluate human natural language explanations in a more objective way. It's a collaborative work from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Northeastern University, and IBM Research. The motivation is to address the subjectivity and task - dependence of human - annotated explanations. Traditional metrics like BLEU and ROUGE are criticized for treating human annotations as gold standards and focusing on word similarity. The proposed matrix, called True, extends the Simulatability score to evaluate the helpfulness of explanations at fine - tuning. The study uses five popular datasets for various tasks and a template - based unified data format. It shows that explanations can be helpful even if considered low - quality by humans. The True score consistently ranks dataset qualities on both T5 and Bart, outperforming the Simulatability score in evaluating some datasets.
The affiliations of the authors are not mentioned in the given text.

The work presents ParaAMR, a large - scale, syntactically diverse paraphrase dataset created through AMR back - translation. It aims to address the lack of syntactic diversity in existing datasets like MRP and PanCora. The key idea is to use AMR graphs, which capture the abstract meaning of sentences. By changing the focus of the graph and using an AMR - to - text generator, ParaAMR can create syntactically diverse paraphrases. The dataset has around 15 million source sentences and 6.9 paraphrases per source sentence. It outperforms other datasets in terms of syntactic diversity while maintaining semantic similarity. The work also demonstrates that ParaAMR benefits NLP applications like learning sentence embeddings, syntactic control of paraphrase generation, and data augmentation for few - shot learning.
The authors use average lagging and computational aware average lagging.

The paper presents a large - scale personalized dialogue dataset called LiveChat. It's constructed from live streaming videos, mainly text - and video - sourced. The key challenge is finding effective matching mechanics for reply - to - relationship capture. Personalized dialogue is crucial for applications like virtual streamers and employees. However, current research faces challenges like insufficient persona information and lack of suitable dialogue turns. The dataset can address the lack of large - scale Chinese multi - party dialogue datasets. It has a unique automatic dialogue construction method. The experiments show that extracted persona and longer average sessions benefit response modeling. For address recognition, single stream better outperforms double stream. The domain of LiveChat is different from existing datasets. The human evaluation results of LM are better in terms of rich informativeness.

The drawbacks of tree - based methods are that trees are usually not given and need to be obtained somehow. This can be complicated and sometimes a computationally expensive process. Typically, it involves considerable formalism - specific pre - processing of the logical forms, for example, to handle variable symbols. Obtaining trees may also involve specialized grammar induction procedures.

The paper introduces a method for compositional generalization without trees in semantic parsing. It uses multi - set tagging and latent permutations. The authors show that their model can handle deeper recursion and unseen compositions better than naive sequence - to - sequence models. They avoid using trees, which can be computationally expensive to obtain. Instead, they directly model the correspondences between input and output fragments. Their approach predicts the output in two steps: tagging input tokens with multi - set tokens and then predicting a permutation. This method is flexible and outperforms other tree - less models on the Cogs benchmark for generalization to deeper recursion. However, other kinds of structural generalization remain challenging. The paper addresses technical challenges like the lack of alignment in training data and the need to induce the correct permutation.

The paper discusses measuring stereotypes in language models using natural language prompts and marked personas. It points out limitations of existing methods like time - consuming datasets and limited generalization. The authors use newer instruction - tuned LMs to generate personas by specifying identity markers in prompts. They analyze generated personas for stereotypes and patterns. The method has two parts: persona generation inspired by a study on human subjects and the marked words method to identify words distinguishing marked groups. Results show generated personas contain more stereotypes than human - written ones, but the lexicon used doesn't capture harmful patterns well. Instead, the marked words method reveals how seemingly positive portrayals reflect harmful stereotypes and essentializing narratives.

The paper discusses the concept of superhuman performance in NLP. It points out that while systems can achieve human - level or even superhuman performance on benchmarks, these achievements are often based on spurious correlations. The authors analyze two popular benchmarks, Super glue and Squad. They find that humans rank 8th on Super glue, outperformed by systems on 6 out of 10 tasks. On average, the best system outperforms humans by 1.5 points. However, there are several errors in the datasets that make the comparison unfair, like systems being evaluated on full test sets while humans on small subsets. The paper also questions the fairness of human baselines, suggesting that simple methods are often used instead of comparing systems to the best possible humans. Overall, it argues that the current evaluation methods are flawed and need improvement.

The paper investigates the generalization of models using the Named Entity Recognition task. It observes that models using CONLL 2003 for 20 years raise questions about their generalization to modern data. To explore this, they developed the CONLL++ dataset from Reuters news in 2020 and annotated it with the same CONLL 2003 guidelines. They fine - tuned over 20 models on CONLL 2003 and evaluated them on both the CONLL 2003 and CONLL++ test sets. They found that three main ingredients are needed for good generalization: a better model architecture, larger model size, and more fine - tuning examples. For performance drop, they proposed two hypotheses: adaptive overfitting and temporal drift. They concluded that CONLL 2003 taggers still work in 2023. The paper calls for more research on improving model generalization.
ABC-Eval stands for Annotating Behaviors in Chat.

The paper introduces Python code generation by asking clarification questions. It addresses the challenge of input under specification in code generation. The authors identify key operations in code and represent them in a latent space. They use schema to compare similarity scores between NLD and operation documentation. If the similarity score is below a threshold, the key operation is considered missing. They also hire annotators to annotate validation and test sets. Templates are used to create CQA for missing key operations, in the form of yes - or - no or multiple - choice questions. The authors use heuristics based on a code knowledge graph to extract key operations. They evaluate their method and find that it performs well in identifying missing key operations. There are some common errors that reflect challenges and potential directions for improvement. The pipeline includes a clarification predictor, question selector, and code generator. The model experiments show that the task is more challenging than existing CQ ranking tasks and that clarifications help code generation. Overall, the paper proposes a new approach to code generation by incorporating interaction through clarification questions.

Hello everyone. My name is Ying and my colleague Zhiyang and I will be presenting our research on MultiInstruct: Improving Multi-Model Zero-Shot Learning via Instruction Tuning.So, with the advances in large language models, many works started to explore new learning paradigms of reusing pre-trained language models for different downstream tasks in a parameter - and data - efficient way. Recently, many studies have shown that instruction tuning enables large language models to perform on unseen tasks in a zero-shot manner by following natural instructions.However, most previous works on instruction tuning focus on improving the zero-shot performance on language - only tasks, while computer vision and multi - model tasks have been left out. Therefore, in this work, we want to investigate whether instruction tuning on multi - model pre - trained models can actually improve generalization to unseen multi - model tasks.Additionally, at the time of our research, we discovered a considerable discrepancy in availability of instruction data set between NLP and multi - model. There exists more than 1, 600 language - only instruction tasks. However, there is no large - scale publicly available multi - model instruction task. Therefore, this motivated us to build a multi - model instruction - tuning data set.Here we present MultiIn

Armen Norbash, a PhD student at Carnegie Mellon University, presents Counter Comp. It uses counterfactual scenarios to improve compositional generalization for multi - step quantitative reasoning. This is mainly about question - answering tasks with financial tables. State - of - the - art models struggle with multi - step tasks as they memorize spurious patterns. The work looks at components of questions that matter for operations in the output. By mining positive and negative examples from the training set, an auxiliary metric learning loss is added to the training procedure. This improves performance on in - distribution and out - of - distribution samples, especially when reasoning steps exceed two. Adding the counter comp loss helps the model attend to more meaningful tokens during training. For more info, check out the poster or contact the listed people.
